column1:
Mike_Marsh,"2014-06-11T20:40:12.893Z","Cargo Train 2014","

I have several Lego train sets and three of them ate based on cargo trains.
column2: This particular set offers some new rolling stock and a different cargo crane to that of 7939. More USA style than European I like this set

column1: instructions as usual are clear and show how to build the set in easy stages.
column2: The box is large and has some great ideas appertaining&nbsp

column1: The parts are packaged well in numbered bags making it easy to build the various items.
column2: The numbers on the bags coincide with the numbered instruction booklets.

column1: The usual high standard of figures including a farmer for the longhorn cow!
Lego really know how to make instructions simple and if you follow the instructions you cannot go wrong.
column2: I spent about three hours putting the whole set together and enjoyed every minute.

column1: This is a North American style locomotive and rolling stock.
column2: The cow depicts a longhorn animal typical of the USA. &nbsp
column3: I like the style, and the rolling stock and believe this is the best version of the cargo train to date.

column1: Overall a typical Lego creation, well thought out, great instructions and added to the vast array of locomotives I already own a great addition to my collection.
column2: Well done again Lego!

m always excited to see a new Lego train, and this train is sufficiently different from the most recent yellow cargo train to warrant picking up. But there are a lot of things with this set that really leave something to be desired, especially given the 200 USD price tag.?
I was happy to see a diesel locomotive and the return of the train doors. The design is somewhat reminiscent of the recent limited release red cargo train, but the interior or &quot
column4: of the train are pretty bare bones. The panels on either side of the engine mask the battery box, which was clever enough, but otherwise the design is pretty basic. That&#39
column5: s not to say it looks bad or out of place, but it is nowhere near as satisfying as any Lego train engine I&#39
column6: ve put together before. I did like how easily this engine incorporated a designated button for activating power function. In that respect, this engine is probably more &quot
column8: than any other RC cargo engine.

column1: The train cars are new designs, and both of the larger cars use a pallet system that has a lot of play value. This is definitely the highlight of this set, and is better than some other cargo systems found before in Lego trains. I like seeing some consistency across different sets, though, and I'
column2: m not sure if these pallets are the same size as what you will find in other cargo sets (planes, trucks, etc.) in the past few years. Regardless, they still can be easily transferred from train car to car, and then to the truck. I thought the wire spools were a neat idea, and a good way to add interest to the set without adding many parts, but I was pretty disappointed with the wheelbarrow pallet. I know its silly to expect to much realism for Lego, but the logistics nerd in me was cringing at the cost of shipping a single wheelbarrow this way!

column1: The cattle car is a fun addition
column2: it is a little smaller than the other cars and would have been improved with just one more animal. However, it kind of feels out of place, given that cattle would probably not be moving through the same intermodal yard that the rest of this cargo would travel through.

column1: The two smaller vehicles are very good, especially compared to past vehicles that accompanied larger train sets. The forklift looks good and is fun to play with, and the truck works seamlessly with the pallet system.

As you can probably see, the crane is a pretty bare-bones affair but it does add some functionality to the set. There is a chair and computer in the little office, but I was pretty unimpressed with the support structure to hold pallets. I doubt the market is there for it, but I would prefer a 60-70 USD standalone set that does a better job a similar crane and office building.
Minifigures are also a high point,the new train personnel look the part and the addition of a farmer was a nice, if not somewhat random, touch.
If you like Lego trains, I imagine you'
column2: ll end up with this set regardless, but I feel that this is a weaker addition to the line compared to the past two cargo trains. The power functions, which I have been generally disappointed with when it comes to how well they can actually pull cargo (especially with the new magnet connectors) add a lot to the price and just aren&#39
column3: t that fun for big train displays. So, I&#39
column4: d keep a close eye on used sets or separated lots so you can either save some money or just get the engine, forklift, or truck.&nbsp

column2: I am a big fan of LEGO&nbsp
column3: trains. However, the recent city trains have left me a little bit flat, until I found this one. &nbsp
column4: This is my first LEGO&nbsp
column5: train purchase in a very long time.&nbsp

column2: height: 300px

The box is huge. Too much so, but I guess with the retail price of $200 US, you need to make an impact on shelf space. The instructions, as others have stated, are super-simplistic. In all honesty, I think even children would find it more fun if some of the instruction steps were combined.&nbsp
The locomotive windshield piece is&nbsp
column3: nice, and there are real train doors. &nbsp
column4: I like the plates that comprise the&nbsp
column5: rear aspect of the locomotive body. &nbsp
column6: A full set of train- related&nbsp
column7: Power Functions is included (requiring 9 AAA batteries for use).

column2: that support the crane are single piece. Effective, but not terribly aesthetic. &nbsp
column3: I would have preferred something different. Also, aside from a computer screen and gages&nbsp
column4: in the loco cab, printed pieces are non existent. If you see it, it&#39
column5: s a sticker.

column1: Returning to the positives, the set comes with right AND left points, 20 pieces of curved track, and 8 straight!
column2: That&#39
column4: It does force the transfer station to be placed on the main-line oval, but allows for a short detour siding. &nbsp
column5: It takes 4 additional pieces of straight track&nbsp
column6: to move the transfer station off of the main oval to its own siding.&nbsp

column2: The minifigures are great! Three men and one lady. All but one have a cap&nbsp
column4: placement, such as a pair of headphones (two included with the set). The minifig printing and&nbsp
column5: colors are &nbsp
column6: excellent. In addition to the headphones, accessories include a garbage can, a dolly/hand truck, a &nbsp
column7: water bucket with handle, and a crate.

column2: height: 177px
The best minifigure of all is a Longhorn steer! It is really, really cool! Definitely a high point of the set.&nbsp
is a very simplistic build with few pieces. &nbsp
column3: Luckily, only the transfer station pillars and two office wall pieces seemed juniorized to me. &nbsp
column4: Nice!

column2: I found it fairly intricate with a smattering of advanced techniques, but nothing too revolutionary. &nbsp
column3: The six-wide truck is a fun little build&nbsp
column4: as well.&nbsp

column2: height: 216px

This was an ideal set to build with my son. While I was working on the locomotive, he tackled the transfer station and part of the rolling stock. We finish the rest together. It was perfect for the situation.&nbsp
The locomotive is really well done. The colors are wonderful and there is enough detail to satisfy an&nbsp
column4: without diminishing playability for the kids. &nbsp
column5: Turning the battery pack&nbsp
column6: on and off by pressing the center fan is really cute. &nbsp
column7: The engineer can enter through train doors in combination with a trap-door roof.&nbsp
column8: Access to the battery pack and infrared receiver is a breeze.&nbsp

column2: height: 209px
As stated, the rolling stock &nbsp
column3: is simple but effective. I must say, I love the cattle&nbsp
column4: car! &nbsp
column5: Sure, it might not be too realistic, but it is perfect for a Lego town!

column2: is simple (but not too simple) and effective. &nbsp
column4: right out of the box, effectively a whole train system in a single set.&nbsp
column5: A truck and forklift are there&nbsp
column6: for handling cargo within and around the transfer station. &nbsp
column8: can be loaded and unloaded to an operator&#39

column2: height: 361px
Marks off&nbsp
column4: First, with a loaded battery pack the locomotive&#39
column5: s center of gravity is so high that it derails on corners more easily than&nbsp
column7: Second, the couplers/bumpers tend to detach themselves fairly easily from the bogie assemblies, especially on the locomotive. &nbsp
column8: Third, although constituting a minority of the set, the&nbsp
column10: crane pillars could have been done better. &nbsp
column11: Lastly, I am not a fan of stickers, but luckily&nbsp
column13: is not a big issue here. &nbsp

column1: This is a very good set, essentially a whole train system in a single box. It can stand by itself for hours of fun, or be
column2: incorporated&nbsp
column4: an&nbsp
column5: extended town. I think there is substance here for the&nbsp
column10: annoyances with the set are easily overcome by the positives.&nbsp

column2: price.&nbsp
column3: $200 USD is the biggest negative of the set. For me, it&#39

column7: I think it is very much worth acquiring. Get one while you can!

,TRUE,4,4,4,5,4 FlagsNZ","2015-10-14T08:51:10.573Z","This is the LEGO train set that started my path onto the LEGO train network","

Last weekend, my seven year old nephew was visiting from
column2: Australia and I made up all my LEGO train sets and laid out all the track.

column1: I have already reviewed 10219 Maersk Train, 7939 Cargo Train and 10233 Horizon Express.
60052 Cargo Train was the set that started my journey into the LEGO train network.
This set comes in a large box with an image on the front showing the entire train yard laid out as well as an inventory of the track sections and a suggested
column2: track layout.

column1: The rear of the box has several close up views of the key components of this set showing the play features. There are some images of the companion
column2: City train sets released in 2014.

column1: • Book 1 with bag 1 makes a green cargo truck.
• Book 2 with bags 2 and 3 makes the blue engine.
<li>Book 3 with bag 4 makes the livestock waggon&nbsp
column2: with a longhorn cow and farmer.

column1: • Book 4 with bag 5 makes the first flat car and two green cable drums.
<li>Book 5 with bag 6 makes the second flat car with an Octan&nbsp
column2: tank, wheel barrow and forklift truck.

column1: • Book 6 with bags 7 and 8 makes the gantry overhead crane and cargo office.
There is a huge sticker sheet with this set which is protected by a cardboard insert in the instruction bag.
The key colour of the engine is bright blue and there are some unique
column2: parts in this colour:

column1: There are four minifigures in this set and a longhorn cow. The set has a truck driver, a forklift driver, engine driver and a farmer with a bucket.

column2: are unique to this set as is the <a href=""http://brickset.com/parts/6032177"">dark green farmer&#39

column1: As the set is split into discrete
column2: modules it is easy to build at a pace that suits you.

column1: The engine closely resembles an American diesel locomotive.
While it is similar to 10219 Maersk Train, it is six studs shorter.

column2: on by pressing down on the middle black disk
column4: and the green LED can be seen which is a great improvement.&nbsp

column1: The engine cab opens up allowing access to the driver.

column2: for the longhorn cow. The cow has a trough to feed from and&nbsp

column1: The key play feature of this set is the yellow gantry overhead crane and cargo office. This differs from the gantry crane in 7939 Cargo Train by being located on a base connected to the tracks.
The five yellow gantry pillars are unique to this set.
The green truck has a large green bonnet
column2: unique to this set,&nbsp
column4: is made up with a large red section. I am not a great fan of these large parts and would prefer a brick built solution.

column1: There are a couple of red trestles
column2: under the crane to support the pallets that are discharged from the train. The fork lift can transfer the cargo to the truck.
20 curved tracks,
column4: left
column5: and&nbsp

column1: Compared with 7939 Cargo Train, this set has four curved tracks in lieu
column2: of the&nbsp
column4: pieces in the earlier set. 16 flexi-tracks&nbsp
column5: have the same length as four regular tracks and would have added some track layout diversity.

column2: self-contained LEGO train set.

column1: The engine is great and there is a great selection of rolling stock.
The cargo handling facility of the gantry crane and a truck with fork lift add playability and will
column2: compliment&nbsp
column3: any existing train sets you may have

column2: a good selection of track pieces but it could have done with some flexi-track sections.

column1: This is a regular LEGO train that is still available in stores. Pick one up before it is retired.

box extremely&nbsp

,TRUE,5,5,5,5,5 ultimatelegofanUK","2015-04-12T09:46:21.09Z","Partly Awesome, Cargo Train","

This was one of the best LEGO&trade
column2: sets I ever got!It was very different from the 60051 train set,which was more streamlined and a more futuristic-looking view,and from the 7939-1 train,which bore a similarity to this set,but more bulky in the front.As always,added bonus with the remote was an extra AWESOME Feature!

column1: The front of the train was pretty unique,actually,compared to previous train models that LEGO has released.The interior was pretty bare,consisting of the remote transmitter and the "
column2: Battery Box&quot
column3: /Engine.The operating of the engine was pretty simple and easy,with one single power switch to turn on/off.

column1: I have to confess,the train cars add a "
column2: farm&quot
column3: landscape to the set,with the OCTAN&reg
column4: Gas tank,the big round things,the forklift(Added AWESOME bonus),cool truck,train and the interesting cargo station.

column1: The Cargo Station was actually pretty cool,because you can move the crane and lower the rope to pick up/transfer cargo onto the truck.The Office was very simple,although adding a touch of elegancy
column2: to the office would have increased the monetary value.

column1: The Power functions was a bit hard to figure out initially,because the instructions manual doesn'
column2: t exactly tell you how to turn on the engine,which took me a bit of time......The Magnet connectors really disappointed me anyways,because when I received the set,and finished building it.

column1: The set was generally playful,especially for a kid'
column2: s imagination....
m a parent of a 4yo son, but also a slight AFOL (loved them as a kid, but getting them for the son has resparked my interest after&nbsp
column3: several decades), so this review mixes both perspectives.

column1: Large box that my son loves to look at.
column2: Heavy cardboard as you would expect for a kit this size.&nbsp
column3: Instructions are in the usual thin stapled booklets of varying sizes.&nbsp
column4: I guess a hardcore fan would prefer a single bound book, but I liked it because it was easy to go through the individual booklets&nbsp
column5: with my son over the course of a three-day holiday weekend, which is what we planned it for.&nbsp

column1: Some of the specialized parts, mostly the metal wheel axles, fork lift rubber band, and hoist string, came in smaller white boxes that were taped shut and slightly annoying to open, but that was because I was lazy and didn&rsquo
column2: t want to get out a knife or scissors. It would have been nice if they had perforated seams (I think the string box did, but not the others).

column1: One thing I noticed is that the picture of the truck in the front (and I think on the booklet as well) is either incorrect or misrepresenting.
column2: There is a half width (2 studs wide) beige crate that holds the grey box container, but this is not included in the set nor in the instructions.&nbsp
column3: There are 4 stud-wide crates for the Octan tank, cable reels, and the green wheelbarrow, but no pieces allocated for the narrower crate shown in the box.

column1: Lots of new and interesting pieces for my son and me since this was our first train set.
column2: Some of the interesting parts were the forklift mechanism using the rubber band, the rails for the hoist and of course the train-specific parts like the wheels,&nbsp
column3: magnet connectors and the electrical parts/remote.&nbsp

column1: Also, we could always do with more track pieces.
column2: I think the set came with enough, but a few more pieces couldn&#39

column1: Nothing too special to say about the minifigures.
With the new parts this was interesting for me as an adult.
column2: A little difficult for my son to assemble most of it, but he was content to just find the parts for me as I was building what he couldn&#39
column4: The cargo yard/hoist was probably the most tricky part because the frames and railing are long.&nbsp
column5: The instructions have you connecting several in a line that is easy to break apart while you are moving on to the next step.&nbsp
column6: You also have to deal with threading the string for the hook.

column1: The way the electrical components and wiring are built in is ingenious
column2: I love how the IR receiver and the on/off button were integrated into the freight engine, pretty slick indeed!
t too complicated and don&#39
column4: to the building experience itself.

column1: Not too many stickers considering the size of the set, and most enhanced the details.
column2: There were a handful I skipped, though.
The sheer size and magnitude&nbsp
column4: The hoist and forklift give a lot of play value, although rotating the red hoist knob is a little cumbersome for the boy when he&rsquo
column5: s playing.&nbsp
column6: The hoist wheels have a tendency to fall off the rails while trying to turn the knob.&nbsp

column2: s a little learning curve, but very easy after you familiarize yourself with the buttons.&nbsp
column3: My son has no trouble using the RC on his own.&nbsp
column5: s a joy to watch him operate the train.

column1: I feel the cattle car is a little out of place for a cargo train that has cable reels and gas tanks.
column2: &nbsp
column3: A box car or another industrial-themed car, perhaps a large oil tanker, would have been much more appreciated.

column2: m not a cow rancher/farmer so I&rsquo
column3: m no expert in identifying cow breeds and genders, but I could swear the cow is a bull because of its long horns, yet the farmer has a red pail with a white stud to represent liquid inside, which I presume to be milk&hellip

column2: m half upset that I bought this because now I want to expand the train collection&hellip
column4: for my son.&nbsp
column5: We&rsquo
column6: ve been through this already with the Thomas the Train wooden train line, and it was not kind to my wallet.&nbsp
column8: t cheap when you factor the price per piece, but they are loads of fun and have tremendous play value.&nbsp
column10: m glad I was able to snag this on sale
column11: the $200 msrp is a bit steep.
